headline: Home Depot & Lowe's Earnings: Turnaround Time?
summary: Both have operated in a challenging environment over recent years, with consumers pulling back on big-ticket items for home improvement following the low-interest-rate era of COVID. With both reaffirming guidance earlier in the year, can the tide finally be turning?

headline: Retail Earnings On Deck This Week: Home Depot, Walmart, Target
summary: Several big-box U.S. retailers are set to report second-quarter earnings this week, offering a glimpse into the spending habits of U.S. consumers and the continued impact of President Trump’s trade war.  Home Depot: The home-improvement chain is set to post earnings on Tuesday morning.  Earlier this year, Chief Financial Officer Richard McPhail said the company won’t raise prices in response to tariffs.

Earlier this year, Chief Financial Officer Richard McPhail said the company won’t raise prices in response to tariffs.

headline: US stocks waver, Jackson Hole, retailer earnings: 3 Things
summary: Here's what Wall Street is watching on Monday, Aug. 18. US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) waver as investors gear up for a busy week with the Federal Reserve, geopolitical tensions, and retail earnings in focus. The market looks for signs about the Fed's next move with the Jackson Hole summit kicking off. Home Depot (HD), Lowe's (LOW), Walmart (WMT), and Target (TGT) report earnings this week, offering a look at the state of the consumer. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Fewer fake firs, higher prices: China tariff delay does little to save the holidays
summary: NEW YORK/SHANGHAI (Reuters) -U.S. shoppers looking for fake Christmas trees and holiday decor this year will have fewer choices and face higher prices as tariffs on Chinese imports force retailers to scale back orders as they assess how tight customer budgets are.  Retailers typically import seasonal goods in advance because many products need six-month lead times.  "We're going to have a lower supply year," said Chris Butler, CEO of National Tree Company, a New Jersey-based artificial tree importer supplying Walmart, Home Depot, Lowe's and Amazon.

raw.headline: Fewer fake firs, higher prices: China tariff delay does little to save the holidays
raw.summary: NEW YORK/SHANGHAI (Reuters) -U.S. shoppers looking for fake Christmas trees and holiday decor this year will have fewer choices and face higher prices as tariffs on Chinese imports force retailers to scale back orders as they assess how tight customer budgets are.  Retailers typically import seasonal goods in advance because many products need six-month lead times.  "We're going to have a lower supply year," said Chris Butler, CEO of National Tree Company, a New Jersey-based artificial tree importer supplying Walmart, Home Depot, Lowe's and Amazon.

headline: Home Depot and Lowe's earnings face housing slowdown, tariffs test
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -Home Depot and Lowe's report earnings this week amid big headwinds, including a stalled U.S. housing market recovery, tariffs, and a consumer allergic to big spending, with investors clamoring for insight on when the storm may pass.  Spring and summer were to be "the Super Bowl season" for home retail, Billy Bastek, Home Depot's executive vice president of merchandising, said on last quarter's earnings call.  Building materials and garden supply retailers saw year-over-year sales drops of at least 4% each month from May to July, even as most others posted growth, according to data from the National Retail Federation (NRF).

raw.headline: Home Depot and Lowe's earnings face housing slowdown, tariffs test
raw.summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -Home Depot and Lowe's report earnings this week amid big headwinds, including a stalled U.S. housing market recovery, tariffs, and a consumer allergic to big spending, with investors clamoring for insight on when the storm may pass.  Spring and summer were to be "the Super Bowl season" for home retail, Billy Bastek, Home Depot's executive vice president of merchandising, said on last quarter's earnings call.  Building materials and garden supply retailers saw year-over-year sales drops of at least 4% each month from May to July, even as most others posted growth, according to data from the National Retail Federation (NRF).
